Posts.Content: Feb 7, 2011 04:32PM - edited Feb 7, 2011 04:35PM by ChrissyMH I am SO SO of one mind with you pejkug and tracie23!  Neither my surgeon nor anyone else laid out neutral options for me in my shocked and crazed 'just-diagnosed' state in mid-October, 2010.  Lumpectomy, then TCx4 chemo - just finished Friday.  Now, I want BLMX and will die trying to get it.  Am I criminally cynical, or is there an element of us being Cash Cows, going month after month after month paying for mammo after U/S after biopsy etc. etc. etc. until we're broke and then we'll just die?  I really believe there is a huge Medical Industrial Complex factor at play and it depresses me.  I think they want cash flow at our expense and mental health. Tell me I'm wrong - I beg.  Do you think my insurance will pay for the BLMX after it already paid for the lumpectomy? thanks..Chrissy

Posts.Content: Apr 30, 2011 10:17AM ChrissyMH wrote: Hi January 2011 folks, I am thinking that folks who had surgery in January 2011 might be best to ask these questions because you all would be about 3 - 4 months out of surgery and have good advice.  I had BLMX-(no reconstruction) on March 24th.  So I am one month post surgery and the cording on my right non-cancer/no-nodes-removed side is just killing me. In addition to the cord, it feels like a wooden panel is in place where a seroma has hardened and a drain was pulled out.  Went to a PT on April 28th and was given 4 exercises, but I've been doing 8 exercises since March 24th from the discharge PT at the hospital - apparently not enough? Does the cording and the feeling of a steel cable around the chest get better? Do you know how long it takes to feel comfortable for hours at a time? Do NSAIDs especially Advil work?  I had been walking for 90 minutes on a treadmill from April 1 - 22, but the PT seems to think that was not a good idea.  I thought walking was supposed to be the best?  Thanks for any info or experiences.

Posts.Content: May 9, 2011 09:47PM - edited May 9, 2011 09:47PM by ChrissyMH For anyone who is, as I was, obsessing about and actually doubting whether or not her hair will regrow:  IT WILL!!  I am living proof.  Super-fine, thin, pale, lame danish hair, getting thinner as I age even before diagnosis and chemo ... I thought it would never return.  My last infusion was on February 4th, 2011.  And today, I verified with my 7X mirror  that every visible follicle now has a sprouting hair, regardless of how fragile and glass-like that strand may be!!  So, for some of us, it takes 100 days, but it REGROWS!!
Posts.Title: Hair Hair Hair - Another question Deen Krose53

Posts.Content: May 7, 2011 08:39PM ChrissyMH wrote: Hi JanetinVA and all, You were right Janet - the physical therapy is essential.  The exercise you mention is one of four that the PT prescribed.  Each is two sets of 12, twice per day.  But despite the improvement in range of motion, if I sit still for a while, say at the keyboard or reading, and then rise, my upper body has already tightened and constricted (like shrinking!) so uncomfortably I get depressed.  You  mentioned that from your first experience, 'it took months'.  Can you elaborate?  Will I ever feel 'good' again?  How did you feel after three months?  6 months?  The cording is still with me of course but stretched much more through the elbows to floor and arms straight over head to floor exercises.  The seroma fluid is gone, but on the right side it persists as a numb, tough, fat lump sitting on top of the two 'cords' that pull and sting.  Then I got an infected toe, gift from my post-chemo weakened immune system according to the podiatrist.  So, now I'm on 7 days of an antibiotic.  Any information on how you healed after your first MX would be so appreciated.  I sorely need to believe that I will be 'normal' at some point in the future.
Posts.Title: March 2011 Mastectomy elmcity69 Glo3mom

Posts.Content: Feb 22, 2011 04:30AM ChrissyMH wrote: Laurie and others, No one suggested BMX when I had a left-side lumpectomy in October.  At the time 5 sentinel and 2 axillary nodes were removed (clean).  I thought there were too few nodes removed to get LE.  Can I still get it???  How do you know you have it?  What are the symptoms?  Just very recently there has been pain and pulling on that side.  Also, now that I am not as completely ignorant of all things BC as I was in October, I too am going to have BMX with a different surgeon at a different hospital - for all the reasons anniealso and many others have stated.  Don't these medical industry 'professionals' get it?  If only I had known.  Better late than never and March 24 can't arrive too soon.

Thanks for any info..

Posts.Content: Apr 24, 2011 01:52PM ChrissyMH wrote: Agnieszka, thank you so much for that information.   I would never have known.  When I went for my 3-week postop with the BS on April 13, I even mentioned the word 'cord'.  She and the nurse offered no information except that I should be able at that point to make 'snow angels' which I cannot - even now, approaching 5 weeks postop.  The next day I called back and asked for a PT referral.  How shall I know of the PT I'm seeing on April 28 knows about Axillary Web Syndrome?  I did not have any nodes removed from the right side.  Thanks again..
Posts.Title: March 2011 Mastectomy elmcity69 Glo3mom

Posts.Content: May 9, 2011 09:29PM ChrissyMH wrote: Janet you are a life-saver and a jewel to share this information.  I have been desperate for answers you have provided.  My right side was prophylactic too.  No nodes ... but the severe cording nevertheless - now you've explained it in terms of the lymphatic fluid.  And you think the dense-dead seroma tissue with resorb too?  Now I can deal with 6 months:  it's finite, with a visible horizon.  I will do the exercises rabidly.  No - the PT has not shown me scar massage.  In fact, I think they assume I know something about massage in general - and I am absolutely CLUELESS.  For example, I learned online about 'myofascial release'.  How could I possibly apply pressure to the cords with my left hand for 3-5 continuous minutes??  On Wednesday I will ask about it all.  I don't know how you ever went through this twice.  Thank you x 10.
Posts.Title: March 2011 Mastectomy elmcity69 Glo3mom

Posts.Content: Jan 9, 2011 10:43PM ChrissyMH wrote: Huntreiter3, I will be candid.  My third of four TC infusions is January 14.  I must be a complete wimp, because I cannot count already the number of times and places I have suddenly burst into tears because of what I assume is the abject depression that overwhelms me when the raw reality of cancer stabs into my mental space.  I am not going to apologize for it.  I don't care that it happens even at work.  In fact, it seems that how others handle my sudden loss of control reveals sometimes surprising things about each of them.  Some people care deeply.  I'm glad I discovered who they are.  Some I believe are fearful - of cancer - and I understand that.  I cannot yet wrap my mind around when and how to 'get over' this depression, sadness and anxiety about the future .. perhaps when it gets closer to the end of the radiation stretch?  You are definitely not alone.  At this time nothing motivates me to be 'positive'.  That seems almost fatuous .. like it's some sort of upper-case denial.  You ARE entitled. __ Diagnosis 12Oct2010; IDC, 1.3cm; Stage 1; Grade 3; 0/7 nodes; triple negative
Posts.Title: Depression Over Good Prognosis? huntreiter3 Momine

Posts.Content: Apr 4, 2011 03:35PM ChrissyMH wrote: Hi all, I must say you all are way braver than I.  I had a March 24th BMX, no node removal (left nodes removed back during a left lumpectomy in mid-October 2010) and no reconstruction.  Four drains that were removed 5 days later.  The drain removal was easily the most painful experience I can remember.  I had no warning ... I don't think I've ever read anything more descriptive than 'uncomfortable' here on BCO re: drain removal.  Am I an uber-wimp? JanetinVA, why did you go for MX and not lumpectomy? Thanks for the tip about massaging the incision line.  My first follow-up is April 13.  Today I can't even imagine massaging anything it stings and hurts so much.   I know what you mean about trying to overdo.  I actually got many stretching exercises to perform from the PT at right discharge!  Did anyone else?  ForMyBoys - the 6" rubber band is the perfect description - and I so agree it's worse than the hours right after surgery.  The whole mess just seems so savage.  I want to focus on health, and the future.  But I did everything 'right' and wound up here.  Sometimes the depression is just too overwhelming.  Especially when there is not a single sign of improvement (still no hair, still rotting nails).  My Medical Onc. wants me to see a psychiatrist and recommended one:  a CHILD PSYCHYATRIST!!!  I looked her up on the Board of Registration!  Not an iota of expressed interest in BC patients or any cancer patients for that matter!  I can only take so many physical and mental insults, and this is just an additional one.  Am I being unreasonable?
Posts.Title: March 2011 Mastectomy elmcity69 Glo3mom

Posts.Content: Apr 20, 2011 05:08PM ChrissyMH wrote: Can anyone tell me if this is normal?  I had BLMX on March 24.  No reconstruction.  Seromas developed on both sides and have subsided .. except that on the right something like a tough cord is pulling and tugging painfully from the armpit to under the right seroma (which is now more like thick tissue, not fluid) and into my right side ribs.  Doing the recommended exercises has now caused medial epicondylitis.  Will this all resolve?  Should I be in this state 4 weeks post surgery?  Should I keep doing the exercises or am I making things worse?  Thanks for any advice or information.
Posts.Title: March 2011 Mastectomy elmcity69 Glo3mom

Posts.Content: Feb 24, 2011 11:44PM ChrissyMH wrote: Hi Russian_Postman! I am scheduled for bilateral mastectomy on Thursday, March 24, at Dana-Farber/Brigham and Women's Hospital here on the U.S. east coast.  The surgeoon said only ONE night in hospital required ... (unless of course something were to go south).  Also, no visiting nurse.  I'm on my own as far as caring for the drains, etc.  Lucky you - no chemo!!  I was Stage 1 also, but Grade 3 (no cancer in any nodes however) so I still had chemo (Taxotere + Cytoxan - 4 infusions over 12 weeks).  Miserable - lost all my hair.  Try to get your pathology report!  All the best...
